Question: Why is an RL trading system particularly well suited to executing high frequency trading strategies?
Answer: High frequency trading occurs at the millisecond and sub-millisecond level. Modifications to an HF trading strategy must also occur on this time scale and so must be decided and implemented by the RL Trader without intervention from a human operator.
The system operator can modify the strategy real-time to take advantage of changes in market conditions
Policy optimization happens immediately before trade execution, so trades are also optimized.
Correct: High frequency trading occurs at the millisecond and sub-millisecond level. Modifications to an HF trading strategy must also occur on this time scale and so must be decided and implemented by the RL Trader without intervention from a human operator.

Question: You have developed an RL algorithm that achieved a high Sharpe ratio and limited drawdowns when applied to the training data set. When you test it using more recent, unseen data, your algo has a zero Sharpe ratio and high PnL volatility. What steps should you take to redevelop your algo so that it has better potential performance in live trading?
Answer: Retrain your algo using a larger data set.
Use a deeper neural network
Increase the dropout percentage in your neural network
Retrain your algo on the testing data set and then test it on the training data set.
Correct: Retrain your algo using a larger data set.
Increase the dropout percentage in your neural network

Question: Portfolio managers can diversify by investing in 20 or more different investments within the asset category they have chosen to focus on. For example they could buy 20 different stocks or 20 bonds issued by different borrowers. Which one of  the options below would achieve the  highest level of risk diversification?

Add 10 foreign currency bonds to a portfolio of 20 stocks.
Increasing the number of stocks or bonds they hold to 30

Question: Portfolio level risk management is just as important, if not more important than strategy level risk management. To some extent strategy level risk management indirectly takes care of firm level risk but it is still desirable to have a separate risk control mechanism that ensures firm survival. What happen when a global stop loss is triggered?
Answer: Trading orders are automatically issued to close out all outstanding trades that currently  have a positive PnL to conserve trading capital and wait for the losing trades to become profitable.
Trading orders are automatically issued to close out all outstanding trades that currently  have a negative PnL to conserve trading capital and wait for the winning trades to offset the losses.
Trading orders are automatically issued to close out all outstanding trades.
Correct: Trading orders are automatically issued to close out all outstanding trades.

Question: Diversification and hedging are important tools that traders and trading firms use on many levels. Please select examples of diversification from the choices below:
Answer: A hedge fund implements a beta-neutral long-short pairs trading strategy that selects similar companies to hedge out market, sector and industry risk.
A hedge fund implements a momentum strategy that goes long several uptrending stocks and short several downtrending stocks.

A hedge fund implements a beta-neutral long-short pairs trading strategy that selects similar companies to hedge out market, sector and industry risk. half of the pairs are chosen using principal components analysis (PCA) and half are chosen based on their level of correlation and cointegration as measured by the adjusted Dickey-Fuller (ADF) test.

A hedge fund implements pairs trading and momentum strategies in equities, foreign exchange and crypto. Within each of these asset classes the strategies are implemented on multiple assets using algorithms that have been developed separately for each asset class.
Correct: A hedge fund implements a momentum strategy that goes long several uptrending stocks and short several downtrending stocks.

A hedge fund implements a beta-neutral long-short pairs trading strategy that selects similar companies to hedge out market, sector and industry risk. half of the pairs are chosen using principal components analysis (PCA) and half are chosen based on their level of correlation and cointegration as measured by the adjusted Dickey-Fuller (ADF) test.

A hedge fund implements pairs trading and momentum strategies in equities, foreign exchange and crypto. Within each of these asset classes the strategies are implemented on multiple assets using algorithms that have been developed separately for each asset class.

Question:
Bridgewater and other hedge funds use a risk parity approach to investing. At its simplest this strategy takes diversified portfolios of assets (or strategies) and increases their potential return by borrowing money to finance them (leverage). In this way a relatively low risk, low return strategy can be financed by a high level of debt so that its potential return on trading capital (not total investment) is much higher. This higher potential return comes with higher potential downside risk though, but this is the standard business model of hedge funds, almost all carry high leverage.

For example lets say you manage a hedge fund that has a diversified portfolio of strategies that when combined yield a relatively low risk income stream of 2% with a volatility of just 1%. How would this compare to an investment in an S&P 500 index fund that has an expected return of 12% and a volatility of 20%? Assume your hedge fund  borrows enough to increase the leveraged risk of its strategy portfolio to the same level as the unleveraged risk of the index fund. What would the leveraged return on the strategy portfolio be? Assume your hedge fund has $1 million of trading capital and $1 million is also invested in the index fund.
